title: Top 10 long weekend escapes in Canada [Photos]
text:
Saturday, September 05, 2015 08:00 AM EDT Top 10 long weekend escapes in Canada Previous Next 
Montreal, Quebec: There's so much to do and see in Montreal. Families can explore the charming, historic cobblestone streets of Old Montreal, stuff themselves full of smoked meat at the famed Schwartz's deli, see superior architecture, like that of the Notre-Dame Basilica, or check out one of Montreal's amazing festivals, like Just for Laughs, the International Jazz Festival or the Montreal Beer Festival. (Postmedia Network/Fotolia) 
Sonora Island, B.C.: An escape to nature has never been so luxurious, thanks to the secluded Sonora Resort in B.C. From kayaking to bear watching to fly fishing, lovers of the outdoors will find plenty to keep them busy. Indoors, guests have access to a gym, mineral pools, wireless Internet service and the Island Currents Spa. Three meals daily are included in the price of your stay, as are snacks, appetizers, beer, wine, liquor and non-alcoholic beverages. Visit sonoraresort.com to book. (Courtesy Darren Bernaerdt/Sonora Resort) 
Vancouver, B.C.: Vancouver is an exciting destination that offers plenty of opportunity for both outdoor experiences -- think biking or hiking in Stanley Park, hitting one of Canada's best urban beaches or setting sail from Vancouver's harbour -- and indoor ones -- like staying at a luxury hotel, gourment dining at one of Vancouver's restaurants or food trucks, or marvelling at more than 70,000 types of fish at the Vancouver Aquarium. (Postmedia Network/Fotolia) 
Churchill, Manitoba: A two-hour flight from Winnipeg, Churchill is an adventurous three-day destination for Canadian families. From polar bear watching to a ride in a tundra buggy, excitement awaits on this remote escape. For added adventure, link up with Lazy Bear Wilderness Expeditions for a float plane ride to the South Knife River and a rafting expedition deep into Manitoba's boreal forest. (Postmedia Network) 
Niagara Falls, Ontario: An ultimate Ontario getaway, Niagara Falls offers so much more for families to see and do besides the world famous waterfalls. Take a spin and get a great view of the Falls on the Clifton Hills Ferris wheel, walk among butterflies at the Butterfly Conservatory, stay at a Falls-view hotel with a water park built right in at the Falls Avenue Resort or, go with just the adults, and take a memorable side trip to the many wineries of Niagara-on-the-Lake. (Postmedia Network) 
Ottawa, Ontario: There's no better time to explore Canada's capital than on a long weekend. Make time to see iconic Canadian historic sites -- the Parliament Buildings and Centennial Flame are a great place to start -- the fun, fresh offerings at the bustling Byward Market -- you can't leave Ottawa without having a BeaverTail pastry at the market. Even U.S. president Barack Obama couldn't resist -- and amazing cultural hot spots like the National Gallery of Canada, Canadian Museum of Nature and Canadian Children's Museum. (Postmedia Network) 
Banff National Park, Alberta: There's a reason Banff is Canada's most popular -- and first -- national park. The stunning vistas and numerous outdoor activities, from camping to hiking to kayaking, make this a must-see Canadian destination. Enjoy a three-day trip in Banff exploring these many activities and more: bike the Banff Legacy Trail, relax in the Upper Hot Springs Pool or swim among waterfalls in Johnston Canyon. (Postmedia Network) 
St. John's, Newfoundland & Labrador: Canada's most easterly point is an exciting Canadian destination that is far from the ordinary. St. John's offers many pleasant surprises, from the high energy night life on George Street to the gourmet seafood at the city's many restaurants. Be sure to take in the stunning views of the Atlantic and see cultural sites like Cape Bonavista Lighthouse, Cape Spear Lighthouse, Castle Hill and Signal Hill. 'Republic of Doyle' fans will especially enjoy St. John's special Doyle tour, with a suggested itinerary available on the office St. John's website -- destinationstjohns.com. (Postmedia Network/Fotolia) 
Dinosaur Provincial Park, Alberta: Did you know you can camp in a real-life Jurassic Park? Alberta's Dinosaur Provincial Park, a UNESCO World Heritage Site 200 km east of Calgary, offers campsites in a working dino dig area. The area is famed for the number of fossils found on site, with more than 40 species discovered here. The Royal Tyrell Museum, another 100 km away, is a great place to see some of the fossils and bones discovered in the area, plus see how the Earth and seas looked in the age of the dinosaurs through special exhibits. (Courtesy Alberta Tourism, Parks & Recreation/Royal Tyrell Museum/Postmedia Network) 
Charlottetown and Green Gables, Prince Edward Island: Charlottetown is an incredible east coast capital, full of history and plenty of spots to dine on fresh seafood. See where Canada was born at Province House, take in a performance at the Confederation Centre of the Arts or step back in time for a fun afternoon with the Confederation Players Walking Tour. Be sure to spend one of your long weekend days on a day trip to Prince Edward Island National Park and Green Gables. In Green Gables, home to Islander Lucy Maude Montgomery's story of Anne, both adults and children will delight in meeting Anne Shirley, exploring the Green Gables farm and house and hearing the history of the tale and how the destination gave birth to Shirley in Montgomery's mind. Be sure to stroll the Haunted Woods on your visit! (Courtesy Tourism PEI/Postmedia Network) Article
